verses.arabic: وَإِذْ قَالَ إِبْرَٰهِۦمُ رَبِّ ٱجْعَلْ هَٰذَا بَلَدًا ءَامِنًۭا وَٱرْزُقْ أَهْلَهُۥ مِنَ ٱلثَّمَرَٰتِ مَنْ ءَامَنَ مِنْهُم بِٱللَّهِ وَٱلْيَوْمِ ٱلْءَاخِرِ ۖ قَالَ وَمَن كَفَرَ فَأُمَتِّعُهُۥ قَلِيلًۭا ثُمَّ أَضْطَرُّهُۥٓ إِلَىٰ عَذَابِ ٱلنَّارِ ۖ وَبِئْسَ ٱلْمَصِيرُ
verses.transliteration: Wa idh qāla Ibrāhīmu Rabbi-j'al hādhā baladan āminan warzuq ahlahu mina ath-thamarāti man āmana minhum billāhi wal-yawmi al-ākhiri qāla wa man kafara fa-umatti'uhu qalīlan thumma adṭarruhu ilā 'adhābi an-nāri wa bi'sa al-maṣīr
verses.translation: And when Abraham said, 'My Lord, make this a secure city and provide its people with fruits - whoever of them believes in Allah and the Last Day.' Allah said, 'And whoever disbelieves - I will grant him enjoyment for a little; then I will force him to the punishment of the Fire, and wretched is the destination.'

grammar.function: Connects this narrative to the previous context
grammar.reason: Links this story of Ibrahim's prayer to the broader narrative of the Prophets and Allah's covenant.
grammar.practical: The simple word for 'and'. It connects this verse to what came before, continuing the story of Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham). When you see 'wa' at the start of a verse, it signals continuation of a theme or narrative. It's like saying 'And remember when...' connecting the dots in the Quran's message.

grammar.function: Points to a specific moment in the past
grammar.reason: Introduces a past event that we should remember and reflect upon. 'Idh' directs our attention to a significant moment in history.
grammar.practical: Means 'when' or 'remember when' - it takes you back to a specific moment in time. When Allah uses 'idh' in the Quran, He's saying 'Remember that time when...' It makes the past event vivid and relevant to us now. This word is telling us to recall and reflect on what Ibrahim did.

grammar.reason: Describes a completed action of speaking in the past. The subject (Ibrahim) will be mentioned next.
grammar.practical: From the root q-w-l meaning 'to say'. 'Qāla' is the past tense: 'he said'. This is one of the most common words in the Quran because it introduces direct speech. The pattern 'fa'ala' (قَالَ) is the standard Form I past tense for 'he did'. When you see 'qāla', expect a quotation to follow - someone's actual words are about to be shared.

grammar.reason: This is the subject (doer) of the verb 'qāla'. The 'u' ending shows it's in the nominative case, which all subjects take.
grammar.practical: The blessed name of Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham), peace be upon him. Ends in 'u' (Ibrāhīmu) because he's the subject - the one doing the saying. Remember: subjects in Arabic always get the 'u' sound (dammah). This is the Quranic pronunciation of Abraham's name, preserving how it was said in Arabic. The alif maqṣūrah (ى) in the middle adds the long 'ā' sound.

grammar.root: ر-ب-ب (r-b-b) - to nourish, to sustain, to be lord
grammar.case: Genitive form with attached pronoun (ī = my)
grammar.reason: Used when directly addressing Allah. The 'ī' at the end is the first person possessive pronoun 'my'. When calling upon Allah, Arabs often drop the vocative particle 'yā' due to closeness.
grammar.practical: 'Rabb' means Lord, Master, Sustainer, Nourisher. The 'ī' makes it 'my Lord' (Rabbī). When making du'a (supplication), we call upon Allah as 'Rabbi' - acknowledging He is our Lord and we are His servants. The 'i' ending (kasra) comes from combining 'Rabb' with 'ī' (my). This intimate form of address shows Ibrahim's close relationship with Allah. The doubled 'b' (shadda) strengthens the meaning.

grammar.root: ج-ع-ل (j-'-l) - to make, to establish, to appoint
grammar.reason: This is a command form, but when directed to Allah, it's actually a humble request/supplication, not an order. In prayer, the imperative form expresses hope and need.
grammar.practical: From ja'ala (to make/establish). 'Ij'al' is the command form: 'Make!' But in du'a to Allah, it means 'Please make' or 'Grant that You make'. The sukūn (no vowel) at the end marks it as imperative. This word is powerful in prayer - asking Allah to CREATE or ESTABLISH something. Ibrahim is humbly requesting Allah to establish security. Note: imperatives in supplication show urgency and sincerity, not disrespect.

grammar.function: Points to something near - the place where Ibrahim was (Makkah)
grammar.reason: Points to the location where Ibrahim was standing when making this prayer. 'Hādhā' is for nearby, visible things.
grammar.practical: Means 'this' - pointing to something close and specific. Ibrahim is pointing to the land around him (Makkah). 'Hādhā' is used for masculine things near you. The alif after the hā gives the long 'ā' sound. When making du'a for a place, you can use 'hādhā' to point to it specifically. This makes the prayer very concrete and specific.

grammar.reason: This is the second object of 'ij'al' (make). The verb 'ja'ala' can take two objects: make THIS (hādhā) a CITY (baladan). The tanwīn 'an' shows it's indefinite accusative.
grammar.practical: Means 'a city' or 'a land'. The 'an' ending (double fatha/tanwīn) has two jobs: 1) Shows it's accusative (receiving the action), 2) Makes it indefinite ('a' city, not 'the' city). So 'baladan' = 'a city'. Ibrahim is asking Allah to transform this barren valley into an established city. The 'an' sound is super common in objects - listen for it when reading Quran.

grammar.root: أ-م-ن (a-m-n) - to be safe, to be secure
grammar.reason: Describes 'baladan' (a city). Adjectives must match their nouns in case, gender, and definiteness. Since 'baladan' is accusative, indefinite, and masculine, 'āminan' must be too.
grammar.practical: Means 'secure' or 'safe'. From the same root as 'īmān' (faith) and 'amīn' (trustworthy). The 'an' ending matches 'baladan' because adjectives copy the noun they describe. Together 'baladan āminan' = 'a secure city'. Beautiful: Ibrahim prays for both physical security AND spiritual security (through faith). When an adjective comes right after a noun with the same ending, it's describing that noun.

grammar.function: Adds another request to the prayer
grammar.practical: Ibrahim is adding a second request: 'Make this secure AND provide sustenance.' The 'wa' builds his supplication.

grammar.root: ر-ز-ق (r-z-q) - to provide, to grant sustenance
grammar.reason: Another request in Ibrahim's prayer. Asking Allah to provide sustenance for the people of this future city.
grammar.practical: From the root r-z-q meaning 'to provide sustenance/provision'. 'Urzuq' = 'Provide!' or in du'a, 'Please provide'. Rizq includes all provision - food, wealth, blessings. Ibrahim shows balance: he asks for security (safety) AND sustenance (provision). A complete prayer addresses both protection and provision. The 'u' at the beginning is characteristic of imperative verbs from this pattern.

grammar.type: Ism - Noun with Pronoun (Direct Object/Maf'ūl bihi)
grammar.components: ahl (people) + hu (its/it, referring to the city)
grammar.reason: The direct object of 'urzuq' - WHO should be provided for. The pronoun 'hu' refers back to 'baladan' (the city).
grammar.practical: 'Ahl' means people, family, or inhabitants. 'Hu' is the possessive pronoun 'its'. Together: 'its people/inhabitants'. The 'a' in 'ahla' shows it's accusative (object being provided for). The full pronoun is 'hu' but when connected to a word ending in 'a', it sounds like 'ahu'. Ibrahim isn't just praying for buildings - he's praying for the PEOPLE who will live there. This shows his concern and foresight.

grammar.function: Shows the source or origin of something
grammar.reason: Indicates where the provision will come FROM. Makes the following noun genitive.
grammar.practical: 'Min' means 'from' - showing origin or source. It answers: 'Provide them from WHERE?' From the fruits. Prepositions like 'min' always make the next word end in 'i' sound (genitive case). This is a key pattern to remember in Arabic grammar.

grammar.reason: The preposition 'min' makes this word genitive. Specifies WHAT provision - fruits and produce.
grammar.practical: Means 'the fruits' or 'produce'. From thamara (fruit/result). The 'i' ending (thamarāti) is because 'min' makes it genitive. The 'āt' in the middle shows feminine plural. Remarkable: this barren valley (Makkah) had no fruits, yet Ibrahim prayed for Allah to provide fruits. His prayer was answered - Makkah became a trade center where fruits from everywhere came! True rizq isn't just what grows locally, but what Allah provides by any means.

grammar.function: Introduces a condition or description of people
grammar.reason: Specifies WHICH of the people should receive provision - those who believe. Can also mean 'whoever'.
grammar.practical: 'Man' means 'whoever' or 'those who'. It introduces a description or condition. Here Ibrahim specifies: provide for THOSE WHO believe. This shows priorities - believers deserve special provision. 'Man' is super versatile - it can refer to one person or many, male or female, as long as they're human. What follows 'man' defines who you're talking about.

grammar.root: أ-م-ن (a-m-n) - to believe, to have faith
grammar.tense: Past tense (but with timeless meaning after 'man')
grammar.reason: Describes the action of believing. After 'man', past tense often has a general timeless meaning: 'whoever believes' (past, present, or future).
grammar.practical: From the root a-m-n (believe/have faith). 'Āmana' = 'he believed'. But after 'man', it means 'whoever believes' (general). Notice this is the same root as 'āminan' (secure) earlier! Security and belief are connected - true security comes through faith. The fatha vowels (a-a-a) are characteristic of Form I past tense pattern.

grammar.reason: Clarifies that the believers are AMONG the inhabitants, not all of them. Some will believe, some won't.
grammar.practical: 'Min' (from/among) + 'hum' (them) = 'minhum' (among them). This specifies: whoever believes FROM AMONG the people. Realistic: not everyone in the city will believe. The sukūn on 'min' and the 'hum' combine smoothly. This teaches us to pray specifically and wisely - Ibrahim asks provision for believers specifically, acknowledging diversity in every community.

grammar.reason: The preposition 'bi' shows what/who they believe IN. Essential for the verb 'āmana' - you believe IN something.
grammar.practical: 'Bi' (in/with) + 'Allāh' = 'billāhi' (in Allah). The 'bi' shows the object of belief - believing IN Allah. The 'i' at the end is because 'bi' makes the following word genitive. The 'al' of 'Allah' merges with 'bi' to form 'billāh'. This is the core of faith: belief in Allah. Notice 'Allāhi' (with kasra) instead of 'Allāhu' - the preposition changed the case.

grammar.function: Adds the second article of faith
grammar.practical: Connects two objects of belief: belief in Allah AND belief in the Last Day. Both are essential.

grammar.reason: Coordinated with 'Allāhi' through 'wa'. Both are genitive after the preposition 'bi'. Shares the same grammatical position.
grammar.practical: 'Yawm' means 'day'. The 'i' ending (yawmi) shows it's genitive, matching 'Allāhi'. Together with the next word, this means 'the Last Day'. Core belief: belief in Allah AND the Day of Judgment. These two beliefs are always paired in the Quran - they're inseparable. When you see 'al-yawm' expect an adjective to specify which day.

grammar.reason: Describes 'al-yawm' (the Day). Adjectives must match their nouns in case (genitive), gender (masculine), and definiteness (definite with 'al').
grammar.practical: Means 'the Last' or 'the Final'. Together: 'al-yawmi al-ākhir' = 'the Last Day' (Day of Judgment). The 'i' ending matches 'yawmi' because adjectives copy their nouns. This is one of the most important beliefs in Islam - that there's a final day of accountability. The Quran constantly pairs belief in Allah with belief in the Last Day to remind us: we'll meet Him and answer for our deeds.

grammar.reason: Introduces Allah's response to Ibrahim's prayer. Same verb as earlier, but now Allah is speaking.
grammar.practical: Same word as before: 'he said' or 'He said' (when referring to Allah). After Ibrahim's prayer, Allah responds. This shows us prayers are heard and answered! The pattern of du'a and response teaches us about conversing with Allah. Notice the shift: Ibrahim spoke, now Allah speaks. The Quran is a dialogue between Creator and creation.

grammar.function: Adds an additional category in Allah's response
grammar.practical: Allah is saying: I'll provide for believers, AND ALSO for those who disbelieve (but with a different outcome).

grammar.reason: Parallels the earlier 'man āmana' (whoever believes). Now: 'man kafara' (whoever disbelieves).
grammar.practical: Same 'man' (whoever) as before, but now for the opposite group. Allah's response is comprehensive: He addresses both believers AND disbelievers. This shows Allah's perfect knowledge and justice - He provides for both, but with different ultimate outcomes.

grammar.root: ك-ف-ر (k-f-r) - to disbelieve, to reject faith, to be ungrateful
grammar.reason: Describes the opposite of 'āmana' (believed). After 'man', means 'whoever disbelieves'.
grammar.practical: From k-f-r meaning to disbelieve or reject faith. 'Kafara' = 'he disbelieved'. The root also means to cover/hide - a disbeliever covers the truth. After 'man', this means 'whoever disbelieves'. Notice the balance: āmana (believed) vs. kafara (disbelieved). The same pattern (fa'ala), different roots, opposite meanings. Allah acknowledges both groups exist.

grammar.reason: 'Fa' means 'so' or 'then' - introducing the result or consequence of disbelieving.
grammar.practical: 'Fa' means 'so' or 'then' - it shows result or sequence. Different from 'wa' (and). 'Fa' implies: 'because they disbelieved, SO/THEN this will happen'. It's a cause-and-effect connector. When you see 'fa', expect a consequence or next step. Here: 'whoever disbelieves, SO/THEN I will grant him temporary enjoyment...'

words.translation: I will grant him enjoyment / I will let him enjoy

grammar.type: Fi'l - Present Tense Verb (Fi'l Muḍāri') with Pronoun
grammar.root: م-ت-ع (m-t-') - to give enjoyment, to provide pleasure/benefit
grammar.reason: Allah speaking in first person, describing what He will do. The 'u' at the beginning indicates first person. The doubled middle letter (tt) shows Form II intensification. The 'hu' is the object - him.
grammar.practical: From m-t-' meaning to enjoy or benefit. Form II 'umatti'u' = 'I will grant enjoyment/pleasure'. The 'u' beginning shows 'I' (Allah). The shadda (doubling) on the 't' makes it Form II - intensive form: 'I will REALLY let him enjoy'. The 'hu' at the end = 'him'. One word in Arabic = 3-4 words in English! Allah promises even disbelievers get worldly provision - this is His mercy and justice. Everyone gets their test.

words.translation: a little / for a little while

grammar.root: ق-ل-ل (q-l-l) - to be little, to be few
grammar.function: Describes the extent or duration - a limited amount
grammar.reason: Limits the enjoyment - it's temporary, not eternal. The 'an' ending shows it's functioning as an adverb of extent.
grammar.practical: Means 'a little' or 'for a little while'. From qalīl (little/few). The 'an' ending makes it accusative, functioning as an adverb describing HOW MUCH enjoyment - only a little. This is key: the enjoyment is 'qalīlan' - brief and limited. Life is short. The worldly pleasures are temporary. This word puts everything in perspective - even if disbelievers seem to prosper, it's only 'qalīlan' compared to eternity.

grammar.function: Shows sequence with a gap or contrast
grammar.reason: 'Thumma' means 'then' but implies a delay or significant transition. Different from 'fa' (immediate consequence).
grammar.practical: 'Thumma' means 'then' or 'after that', but with a sense of delay or contrast. Different from 'fa' (immediate). Here it shows: FIRST temporary enjoyment in this life, THEN (after death) the consequences. The gap between 'thumma' clauses makes it dramatic. It's like: 'first this... BUT THEN...' The contrast makes the second part more striking. A short life of pleasure, THEN eternal consequences.

words.translation: I will force him / I will compel him

grammar.type: Fi'l - Present Tense Verb (Fi'l Muḍāri') with Pronoun
grammar.root: ض-ط-ر (ḍ-ṭ-r) - to compel, to force, to drive to necessity
grammar.form: Form I but with unique pattern
grammar.reason: Continues Allah's first-person speech. Describes forceful compulsion - no escape. The 'a' beginning marks first person present tense.
grammar.practical: From ḍ-ṭ-r meaning to force or compel out of necessity. 'Adṭarru' = 'I will force/compel'. The 'a' at the start shows 'I' (first person). The doubling of 'r' (shadda) intensifies: strong compulsion, no choice. The 'hu' = 'him'. Together: 'I will force him'. Powerful word: adṭarru means to compel someone who has no choice, driven by necessity. After a brief life of choice, comes inevitable accountability. No one can escape Allah's justice.

grammar.reason: Indicates WHERE they will be forced to - toward the punishment. Makes the following noun genitive.
grammar.practical: 'Ilā' means 'to' or 'toward' - showing direction or destination. It answers: forced TO WHERE? To the punishment. Like 'min' (from), the preposition 'ilā' makes the next word genitive (ending in 'i'). Common in Quran to show spiritual or physical direction. This word marks the destination - and it's not pleasant for those who rejected faith.

grammar.type: Ism - Noun (Muḍāf - first part of possessive construction)
grammar.reason: The preposition 'ilā' makes it genitive. This is also the first part of an iḍāfa (possessive): 'punishment OF the Fire'.
grammar.practical: Means 'punishment' or 'torment'. From '-dh-b (to punish). The 'i' ending is for two reasons: 1) the preposition 'ilā', 2) it's in an iḍāfa construction (possessive). When a word is in the middle (after a preposition, before another noun), it gets 'i'. The word is indefinite, but the iḍāfa will define it: 'punishment of the Fire' (specific punishment). Serious consequence after rejecting truth.

grammar.type: Ism - Noun (Muḍāf ilayhi - second part of possessive construction)
grammar.reason: Second part of iḍāfa (possessive construction). Always takes genitive case. Defines which punishment - the punishment OF the Fire (Hellfire).
grammar.practical: 'Nār' means fire. The 'i' ending (nāri) shows it's genitive - second noun in possessive construction. Together: 'adhābi an-nāri' = 'punishment OF the Fire'. The 'al' makes it definite: THE Fire (Hellfire, Jahannam). When you see two nouns in a row, often the second defines/possesses the first: punishment OF the Fire. The iḍāfa creates powerful, specific meanings. Here: the ultimate punishment - Hellfire itself.

grammar.function: Adds a concluding statement about the destination
grammar.practical: Introduces a final comment about how terrible this destination is.

words.translation: wretched is / evil is / how terrible is

grammar.root: ب-ء-س (b-'-s) - to be bad, to be wretched
grammar.form: Special form for expressions of blame/praise
grammar.reason: 'Bi'sa' is a unique verb form used only for expressing blame or criticism. It's always in this form and is followed by what's being condemned.
grammar.practical: 'Bi'sa' is a special word meaning 'how terrible!' or 'how wretched!' It's used to express strong condemnation. This is one of the 'verbs of praise and blame' in Arabic - fixed expressions. 'Bi'sa' + noun = 'What a terrible [noun]!' Opposite is 'ni'ma' (how excellent!). Here it emphasizes: that destination (Hellfire) is THE WORST possible destination. Fixed phrase used throughout the Quran to condemn evil things.

words.translation: the destination / the final abode / the return

grammar.root: ص-ي-ر (ṣ-y-r) - to become, to end up, to return
grammar.reason: The subject being condemned by 'bi'sa'. Must be definite (with 'al') and nominative. Represents the Fire as a destination.
grammar.practical: From ṣ-y-r meaning to become/return. 'Maṣīr' means destination, final abode, or where you end up. The 'u' ending shows it's the subject (nominative). Together: 'bi'sa al-maṣīr' = 'What a terrible destination!' This is a common Quranic phrase condemning Hellfire. The word 'maṣīr' reminds us: we all have a final destination (ma- prefix often indicates place). Where we end up depends on our choices in this life. Powerful ending to the verse.
